Award.AwardTitle: Particle Physics at High Energy Colliders
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal requests continuing support for a program of research for the Huston.Bromberg group at Michigan State University (MSU) in experimental elementary particle physics based primarily on the CDF experiment and proposed NOvA experiment at the Fermilab Tevatron collider and the ATLAS experiment at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN.

For the past few decades, physicists have been able to describe with increasing detail the fundamental particles that make up the Universe and the interactions between them. Much of this success has been due to the Tevatron program at Fermilab with D0 and CDF making major contributions. This understanding is encapsulated in the Standard Model of particle physics, but it contains gaps and cannot tell us the whole story. To fill in the missing knowledge requires more and different experimental data, and the next big step to achieving this is with the LHC. This MSU group has made major contributions to the CDF experiment in its design, construction and operation of parts of the calorimeter and tracker and in the physics questions proposed as well as in many leadership roles. This group is now transitioning into the ATLAS program where it will parlay its wealth of experience in W/Z + jet final state(s) into a leadership role in such analyses. Such events serve as both a signal channel and background in Standard Model and Beyond the Standard Model physics. The group also has major responsibility in the design, installation and operation for parts of the calorimeter system including thee L1 trigger. This group works closely with phenomenologists with Huston serving as co-spokesman for the 24 member Coordinated Theoretical-Experimental Project on QCD (CTEQ) and one of the organizers of its workshops.

Bromberg also is participating in the NOvA R&D program with his group having responsibility for quality assurance of the 13,000 km of WLS fiber. Finally, he has also joined the group testing a 250-liter LArTPC at Fermilab.

On Broader Impacts, the group will continue its work primarily within the QuarkNet program as well as employing undergraduates in the research. Expansion of the Cosmic Ray Detector units into other schools is underway with the goal of coordinating time stamps between high schools to look for wide area cosmic ray showers. Science Days and permanent exhibits in an atrium setting at MSU related to the ATLAS program are planned.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research funded by this grant took place at two high energy physics laboratories, Fermilab and CERN. The work included research at two high energy colliders, the Fermilab Tevatron and the CERN Large Hadron Collider (LHC), as well as the Fermilab neutrino beam. The Fermilab Tevatron was a proton-antiproton collider operating producing the (before 2008) highest energy collisions in the world. The MSU group worked on the CDF experiment mostly studying the properties of top-antitop quark final states, measuring both the rate for the production of an additional jet, as well as the forward-backward asymmetry for the production of a top (anti-top) quark. The top quark is by far the heaviest quark and may be more sensitive to any new physics beyond the standard model that may exist. The asymmetry measurements are of particular interest in this light, and the larger than expected values of the asymmetry have created a great deal of interest in this possibility. The Fermilab Tevatron shut down permanently in 2011, but the data analysis will continue for at least the next year as we attempt to extract as much physics as possible from this unique data sample. 

Since 2008, the CERN LHC has produced the highest energy collisions (protons on protons). The MSU group is a member of the ATLAS collaboration and has studied a variety of physics topics with the 7 TeV proton-proton collisions. These have included the production of photons, of jets, of W bosons accompanied by jets, and of the production of Higgs bosons. All of the above final states can be compared to predictions from precision calculations involving perturbative Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD). In most cases, the data are in good agrement with the theoretical predictions. Although its existence has not been confirmed yet, there is evidence that the Higgs boson does exist, at a mass of about 125 billion electron-volts. 

For over a decade, it has been known that neutrinos can oscillate from one type to another. This is possible only if there is a mass difference among the different types of neutrinos. Precision measurements of such oscillations may help to understand these mass differences and to understand whether there is charge-parity (CP) violation in the neutrino sector. Such a discovery could help us to understand a critical question, why there is more matter than anti-matter in the universe.
